questions.text: A 30 y/o woman presents for her first prenatal visit. She’s a Primi and is concerned about her pregnancy, as her mother experienced pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) during her pregnancies. She is currently healthy and denies any medical problems. She is a smoker, and her BMI is 31. Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for PIH?

A 32-year-old pregnant woman is receiving magnesium sulfate for the management of severe preeclampsia. After several hours of infusion, she exhibits diminished patellar reflexes and mild respiratory depression. Her serum magnesium level is found to be 12 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate antidote for magnesium sulfate toxicity in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Serum Magnesium Level

Effect

5-9 mg/dL

Therapeutic range

9 mg/dL

Loss of patellar reflexes

12 mg/dL

Respiratory depression occurs at ~12 mEq/L (14.4 mg/dL) due to muscle paralysis

30 mg/dL

Cardiac arrest

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with symptoms of eclampsia. The medical team decides to administer magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for seizure prophylaxis. Which of the following correctly describes the regimen for magnesium sulfate administration ?

options.label: A
options.text: Pritchard: 4 g IV, then 1-2 g/hour IV infusion.

options.label: B
options.text: Zuspan: 4 g IV, then 10 g IM (5 g each buttock).

options.label: C
options.text: Pritchard: 4 g IV, then 10 g IM, 5 g IM every 4 hours.

options.label: D
options.text: Zuspan: 4 g IV, then 5 g IM every 4 hours.

questions.correct_answer: C. Pritchard: 4 g IV, then 10 g IM, 5 g IM every 4 hours.
questions.explanation:
Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Notes

Pritchard

(IV and IM)

(Option A ruled out)
  • Administer 4 g IV over 3-5 mins (20 mL of 20% MgSO4 solution)
  • Follow with 10 g of 50% MgSO4 solution: 5 g (10 mL of 50% solution) in each buttock as deep IM injection with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in the same syringe.
  • 5g IM with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in alternate buttocks every 4 hours; continue for 24 hours after birth or last convulsion

If convulsions recur after 15 min, give 2 g IV over 5 min (20% solution).

Zuspan

(IV only)

(Option B & D ruled out)
  • Administer 4-6 g IV over 15- 20 mins (20 mL of 20% magnesium sulfate solution).
  • If convulsions recur after 15 mins, give 2g IV (10 mL of 20% MgSO4 solution) over 5 mins.
  • 1-2 g IV infusion per hour (5 mL of 20% solution); continue for 24 hours after childbirth or last convulsion

Use an infusion pump if available. Ensure dilution to 20% solution.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman with severe preeclampsia is receiving magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis. Her current serum magnesium level is 7.5 mg/dL. What does this indicate regarding her magnesium sulfate therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: The level is within the therapeutic range for magnesium sulfate.

options.label: B
options.text: The level is below the therapeutic range for magnesium sulfate.

options.label: C
options.text: The level indicates the potential toxicity of magnesium sulfate.

options.label: D
options.text: The level indicates a need for immediate cessation of magnesium sulfate.

questions.correct_answer: A. The level is within the therapeutic range for magnesium sulfate.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

MOA
  • NMDA Receptor Blockade
  • Calcium Channel Blockade: Reduces calcium influx into neurons.
  • Vasodilation: Improves cerebral blood flow and reduces cerebral edema, dilates uterine arteries, increases endothelial prostacyclin production and inhibits platelet activation.

Uses
  • Prevent seizures in severe preeclampsia and eclampsia. Prevent recurrent seizures in eclampsia.
  • Tocolytic effect (delaying preterm labor).
  • Neuroprotective: Protects the preterm baby's brain from damage by reducing the risk of cerebral palsy.

Therapeutic Range
  • To control fits, the optimum serum magnesium is 4.8–8.4 mg/dL (4–7 mEq/L). Deep tendon reflex loss at 9 mg/dL (>7 mEq/L).

C/I
  • Myasthenia gravis, hypocalcemia, moderate-to-severe renal failure, cardiac ischemia, heart block, myocarditis.
  • Avoid if alternatives are justified.

Administration and Dosage
  • Administer: Intravenously or intramuscularly.
  • Loading dose: 4–6 g IV over 20–30 minutes. (Zuspan or Sibai regimen)
  • Maintenance: 1–2 g/hour IV. Monitor urine output and reflexes.

Dosage Adjustment
  • Adjust for renal dysfunction.

Adverse Effects
  • Primarily smooth muscle relaxant: Respiratory depression (at 12 mg/dL) and cardiac arrest (at 30 mg/dL).
  • Manage with calcium gluconate 10% and furosemide if needed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the clinic with blood pressure readings consistently around 160/104 mmHg. She has no proteinuria or other symptoms of end-organ damage. She is diagnosed with gestational hypertension. Which antihypertensive medication is considered the first-line treatment for managing this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Drug Class

Examples

Notes

Beta-blockers

Labetalol

Preferred. Generally safe and effective

Calcium channel blockers

Nifedipine (Option A ruled out),

Amlodipine

Safe, less BP variability compared to labetalol

Drug Class

Examples

Notes

Vasodilators

Hydralazine (Option C ruled out)

Reserved for cases with cardiac/renal dysfunction

Drug Class

Examples

Notes

ACE inhibitors

Enalapril, Lisinopril

Associated with severe fetal malformations

Angiotensin-receptor blockers

Losartan, Valsartan

Not recommended at any point during pregnancy

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents at 30 weeks of gestation with BP of 170/110 mmHg and proteinuria. She is stable without evidence of end-organ damage. According to the algorithm for managing severe preeclampsia, what is the recommended management approach?

options.label: B
options.text: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care centre

options.label: C
options.text: Monitor closely for 24 hours and discharge

options.label: D
options.text: Administer antenatal corticosteroids and terminate pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: B. Consider expectant management in a tertiary care centre
questions.explanation:
Algorithm for Treating Preeclampsia

Initial Evaluation
  • Perform comprehensive maternal and fetal evaluation.
  • CBC with platelet estimate, serum creatinine, LDH, AST, ALT, and proteinuria testing.
  • Fetal evaluation: USG for estimated fetal weight, amniotic fluid volume, and fetal antepartum testing.

Decision for Delivery vs Expectant Management
  • 34+ Weeks Gestation: Deliver promptly upon maternal stabilization or with labor/prelabor rupture of membranes; do not delay for steroid administration.
  • Before 34 Weeks Gestation with Severe Preeclampsia: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care setting if maternal and fetal conditions are stable.
  • 37+ Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Opt for delivery rather than expectant management upon diagnosis.
  • Before 37 Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Managed as an outpatient; requires frequent fetal and maternal evaluation. Deliver only if specific conditions necessitate immediate intervention.

Management During Expectant Management
  • Closely monitor maternal and fetal conditions.
  • Serial laboratory testing: CBC, liver enzymes, serum creatinine.
  • Use antihypertensive therapy for acute-onset severe hypertension (systolic ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic ≥110 mm Hg).
  • Administer antenatal corticosteroids and monitor for 48 hours if delivery is indicated before 34 weeks gestation. 

Regularly check for Conditions Necessitating Delivery Regardless of Gestational Age

Maternal Conditions

Fetal Conditions
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia
  • Suspected acute placental abruption, or vaginal bleeding without placenta previa
  • Uncontrolled severe-range blood pressure
  • Worsening renal function
  • Persistent headaches, epigastric/right upper quadrant pain
  • Visual disturbances
  • Motor deficits
  • Altered sensorium
  • Stroke
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Abnormal fetal testing
  • Fetal death
  • Fetus with low survival likelihood (lethal anomaly, Extreme prematurity)
  • Persistent reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

Postpartum Management
  • Monitor blood pressure and symptoms post-delivery.
  • Consider NSAIDs for pain management instead of opioids.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions doesn’t typically require immediate termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age?

options.label: A
options.text: Pre-eclampsia with severe features and stable maternal and fetal conditions

questions.correct_answer: A. Pre-eclampsia with severe features and stable maternal and fetal conditions
questions.explanation:
CONDITION

DELIVERY TIMING

Chronic hypertension not on medications

38w0d – 39w6d

Chronic hypertension controlled by medications

37w0d – 39w6d

Chronic hypertension not well controlled by medications

36w0d – 37w6d

Chronic Hypertension with Superimposed Preeclampsia

37weeks

Gestational hypertension

37weeks

Pre-eclampsia without severe features

37weeks

Pre-eclampsia and Gestational Hypertension with severe features

34weeks

Pre-eclampsia with severe features, unstable or prior to viability

Delivery after maternal stabilization

Maternal Conditions

Conditions Necessitating Delivery Regardless of Gestational Age
  • HELLP syndrome (Option B ruled out)
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia & Impending Eclampsia (Option C ruled out)
  • Suspected acute placental abruption or vaginal bleeding without placenta previa
  • Uncontrolled severe-range blood pressure
  • Worsening renal function
  • Persistent headaches, epigastric/right upper quadrant pain
  • Visual disturbances
  • Motor deficits
  • Altered sensorium
  • Stroke
  • Myocardial infarction

Fetal Conditions
  • Abnormal fetal testing
  • Fetal death
  • Fetus with low survival likelihood (lethal anomaly, extreme prematurity)
  • Persistent reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

questions.text: A 28 y/o primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg on two separate occasions, six hours apart. She has no prior history of hypertension. Her urine protein creatinine ratio is 0.4. On P/A exam, SFH is 32 cm, FHS 140/min, uterus is relaxed and she is perceiving normal fetal movements. What is the most appropriate frequency for fetal monitoring in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring every 2 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: FHR monitoring weekly along with fetal surveillance.

options.label: D
options.text: No fetal monitoring is necessary at this time

questions.correct_answer: B. FHR monitoring weekly along with fetal surveillance.
questions.explanation:
Mild pre-eclampsia

Severe Pre-eclampsia

Weekly fetal heart rate monitoring and regular prenatal checkups with a focus on:

  • Monitoring BP.
  • Proteinuria.
  • Fetal well-being
  • The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is the preferred method of fetal assessment in severe cases.
  • Parameters to be monitored:
    • NST
    • Fetal movements, breathing, fetal tone
    • Amniotic fluid volume

Umbilical artery Doppler finding

Delivery Timing based on finding

UA reversed diastolic flow

Deliver between 30 to 32 weeks

UA absent diastolic flow

Deliver between 33 and 34 weeks

UA pulsatility index (PI) abnormal (PI >95th percentile)

Deliver at 37 weeks
 

UA PI normal (PI ≤95th percentile):

EFW <3rd percentile and no comorbidities 

Deliver at 37 weeks

EFW ≥3rd and <10th percentile and no comorbidities

 

Deliver between 38 and 39 weeks

EFW ≥3rd and <10th percentile with oligohydramnios or comorbidities (e.g., preeclampsia, chronic hypertension) -

Timing individualized; Most should deliver between 34 and 37+6 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is a well-established risk factor for the development of Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension (PIH), including preeclampsia and gestational hypertension?

options.label: B
options.text: Previous pregnancy with the same partner

options.label: C
options.text: Exposure to chorionic villi for the first time

options.label: D
options.text: High levels of cell-free DNA in maternal serum

questions.correct_answer: C. Exposure to chorionic villi for the first time
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Risk Factors for PIH

Prior preeclampsia, chronic hypertension, diabetes, renal disease, autoimmune disorders

Nulliparity

First pregnancy; first exposure to chorionic villi increases PIH risk

Multifetal gestation

Increased chorionic villi quantity linked to higher risk

Maternal age & Obesity

Age > 35 years and obesity increase risk

Family history

Positive family history increases risk

Smoking

Paradoxically associated with lower PIH risk

Biological markers

Angiogenic imbalance (sFlt-1, PlGF), endothelial dysfunction are under study, not established for clinical use

Cell-free DNA

Investigational; no proven predictive value

questions.text: A 38 y/o woman presents for her first prenatal visit. She is excited about the pregnancy but expresses concern about her family history of preeclampsia in her mother. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no history of hypertension. What is most likely recommended by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) to reduce this patient's risk of developing preeclampsia?

options.label: C
options.text: Prophylactic Anti-hypertensive at 20 weeks of gestation.

questions.explanation:
Method

ACOG Recommendation

Effectiveness

Low-dose Aspirin

Women at high risk for preeclampsia.

Low-dose aspirin (75-150 mg/day) initiated between 12 and 28 weeks of gestation.

Chronic Conditions

Controlling diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, and renal disease.

Pre-conception and early pregnancy management

Lifestyle modifications

Healthy diet, regular physical activity, weight management

Emphasizes overall health

Avoidance of bed rest

Advises against bed rest

Bed rest may cause Thromboembolic events. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 32 Y/o woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of persistent headaches and visual disturbances. On examination, her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and she has 2+ proteinuria on a urine dipstick test. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gestational HTN (Option A ruled out)
  • BP >140/90 after 20 weeks gestation at 2 separate occasions 6 hrs apart in a previously normotensive woman without proteinuria or end organ damage

Chronic HTN (Option B ruled out)
  • Pre-existing HTN presenting < 20 weeks of gestation

Acute on chronic HTN
  • Chronic HTN patient with superimposed gestational HTN
  • New onset proteinuria after 20 weeks gestation

Preeclampsia (Option C)
  • BP >140/90 after 20 weeks gestation associated with:
  • Proteinuria: ≥300 mg/24 h of urine or 1+ on urine dipstick
  • Urine protein: Creatinine >0.3

Or

  • End organ damage: Platelets <1,00,000/microL; Creatinine >1.1 mg/dL; doubling of serum transaminase level; headache, visual disturbances

Eclampsia (Option D ruled out)
  • Preeclampsia + generalized tonic-clonic seizures

Delta HTN
  • Sudden rise in mean arterial pressure in pregnant women, even though being at normal levels

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in her third trimester presents to the labor and delivery unit with a blood pressure of 165/110 mm Hg, severe headache, and visual disturbances. She reports she has been experiencing swelling in her legs and face for the past week. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria. Which of the following maternal systemic effects is the MOST likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.explanation:
Pathophysiology

Presentation

Renal

Reduced blood flow to the kidneys causes damage to the glomeruli.

Proteinuria, renal insufficiency (increased creatinine), AKI. (Option B)

Cardiovascular

  • Increased afterload due to hypertension.
  • Reduced preload due to diminished blood volume expansion.
  • Endothelial activation - Fluid leakage and edema.

Hypertension, decreased cardiac output, Pulmonary edema.

Neurological

  • Vasospasm leading to reduced blood flow and ischemia.
  • Increased capillary permeability in the brain.

Headaches, Visual disturbances, Seizures (eclampsia).

Hematological

  • Activation of the coagulation cascade.
  • Endothelial damage and platelet deposition.

Thrombocytopenia, Hypercoagulability (Blood clot formation) (Options D)

Hepatological

  • Reduced blood flow to the liver.
  • Systemic inflammation and oxidative stress.

Elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT), HELLP syndrome (Elevated liver enzymes and low platelets) (Option C)

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida presents at 26 weeks gestation, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated so far. Her blood pressure is measured at 150/95 mmHg on two occasions, 6 hours apart. A urine dipstick test shows proteinuria. What is the most likely mediator involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Factors involved in pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH)

Factors

Explanation

Exposure to chorionic villi

First-time exposure to chorionic villi - High risk of PIH.

Amount of chorionic villi

Twins or a hydatidiform mole.

Pre-existing maternal conditions

Chronic hypertension, Renal disease, Obesity, Connective tissue disorders, Diabetes.

Abnormal placental implantation

Incomplete invasion of uterine vessels by trophoblasts.

Maternal immune response

Loss of maternal immune tolerance to placental and fetal antigens. Increased Th1 cell function causes decreased vascular modification.

Angiogenic imbalance

Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1) and Soluble endoglin (sEng).

questions.text: A 38 y/o primigravida presents at 32 weeks gestation with a blood pressure of 165/115 mmHg and new-onset proteinuria. She has a persistent headache and blurry vision. What pathophysiologic change is most likely responsible for her clinical diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Normal Pregnancy

Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension (PIH)

Placentation
  • Extravillous trophoblasts invade the spiral arteries of the uterus around week 20.
  • This invasion widens the spiral arteries.
  • The widening enhances blood flow to the placenta.
  • This is known as secondary placentation.
  • Incomplete invasion of the spiral arteries by extravillous trophoblasts.
  • Persistent narrow vessels with reduced blood flow and placental ischemia.

Immune Response

T-helper 2 cells dominate, promoting humoral immunity and tolerance of the fetal antigens.
  • A shift towards T-helper 1 cell activity.
  • Increasing the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, γ-interferon, IL-2).
  • Contributing to endothelial dysfunction.

Endothelial Function

Maintains normal vascular tone and permeability, regulating blood flow and preventing inappropriate clotting.

Endothelial cells become dysfunctional, leading to vasoconstriction, increased permeability (edema), and activation of the coagulation cascade.

Angiogenic Balance
  • Pro-angiogenic factors (VEGF, PlGF, TGF-β) promote blood vessel growth.
  • Anti-angiogenic factors (sFlt-1, sEng) inhibit blood vessel growth.
  • A balance between these factors is essential for proper placental development and function.
  • Imbalance occurs with elevated production of anti-angiogenic factors (sFlt-1, sEng).
  • Reduced levels of pro-angiogenic factors are observed.
  • sFlt-1 binds to and deactivates VEGF and PlGF.
  • sEng inhibits TGF-β signaling.
  • This imbalance leads to endothelial dysfunction and impaired angiogenesis

Blood Pressure

Blood pressure remains within the normal range due to the vasodilatory effects of pregnancy hormones
  • Hypertension occurs after 20 weeks of pregnancy, characterized by blood pressure over 140/90 mmHg.
  • It results from vasoconstriction, endothelial dysfunction, and heightened sensitivity to vasopressors.

questions.text: A 32 Y/o woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe upper abdominal pain, headache, and visual disturbances. She has no history of hypertension or proteinuria during this pregnancy. On examination, her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and there is no significant proteinuria on a dipstick test. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes and thrombocytopenia. Which of the following is the initial management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer antihypertensive medication to control blood pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Start magnesium sulfate infusion to prevent seizures.

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate corticosteroids to promote fetal lung maturity

questions.correct_answer: C. Start magnesium sulfate infusion to prevent seizures.

questions.text: A 28 Y/o pregnant woman in her second trimester at 24 weeks of gestation visits the prenatal clinic for a routine check-up. She has a history of hypertension, and her first pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia. Which of the following is best to reduce the risk of preeclampsia in this pregnancy?

options.label: C
options.text: Routine use of antihypertensive medications in the first trimester

questions.text: A 32 Y/o pregnant woman at 35 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, and headaches. Blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg. Laboratory results reveal hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and a low platelet count. Which of the following is the definitive management for a patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
HELLP Syndrome:

Rare complication of Preeclampsia, which usually occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy

Features:

  • H- Hemolysis
  • EL- Elevated Liver enzymes
  • LP- Low Platelets

Risk factors:

  • HELLP in prior pregnancy, age >35, multiparous, history of diabetes, kidney disease

Symptoms:

  • RUQ pain, headache, blurred vision, nausea, vomiting, edema

Maternal complications:

  • Blood clotting problems, DIC
  • Kidney failure
  • Liver failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia

Fetal complications:

  • Preterm birth
  • Growth restriction
  • Respiratory distress

Treatment:

  • Majority of patients develop eclampsia- MgSO4 to prevent seizures (Option C)
  • Antihypertensives to control BP (Option B)
  • If <34 weeks, Corticosteroids for lung maturity (Option D)
  • Definitive treatment: Termination of pregnancy (Option A)

Differential diagnosis: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents with severe headache, visual disturbances, and epigastric pain. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg, and she has +3 pitting edema in her lower extremities. Laboratory results reveal proteinuria. All of the following are signs /symptoms of impending eclampsia except?
Which of the following findings indicates Severe Preeclampsia?
questions.explanation:
Abnormality

Non-severe

Severe

Systolic BP

<160 mm Hg (Option A ruled out)

≥160 mm Hg

Diastolic BP

<110 mm Hg

≥110 mm Hg

Proteinuria

300 mg/24 hours or 1+ on urine dipstick (Option B ruled out)

>5 gm/ 24 hours or 3+ on urine dipstick

Headache and visual disturbances

Absent

Present

Upper abdominal pain

Absent

Present

Oliguria

Absent

Present

Thrombocytopenia (<100000 /microL)

Absent

Present

Serum creatinine

Normal

Elevated (Option D)

Serum transaminases

Minimally elevated

Markedly elevated

Fetal growth restriction

Absent

Present

Pulmonary edema

Absent

Present

questions.text: A 37 y/o multigravida with a history of chronic hypertension, at 28 weeks twin gestation, presents with occasional headaches and visual disturbances. Her blood pressure is measured at 150/95 mmHg, and a urine dipstick test reveals significant proteinuria. Which of the following is not a risk factor for preeclampsia for this patient?
